dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Facebook's poker AI, Pluribus, just crushed top human pros in multiplayer Texas hold'em.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Facebook's poker A I, Pluribus, just crushed top human pros in multiplayer Texas hold'em.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Pluribus beat top-ranked professional players in both a five AIs plus one human player format and a one AI plus five professionals format.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Oh yeah, I read about that—it was developed by Noam Brown and Thomas Sandholm, right? The paper came out in Science on May 30th.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh yeah, I read about that-it was developed by Noam Brown and Thomas Sandholm, right? The paper came out in Science on May thirtieth.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: It was described in an academic paper published in the journal Science on Thursday.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. And what's wild is it learned entirely through self-play, no human data at all. Just started from random moves and refined itself.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. And what's wild is it learned entirely through self-play, no human data at all. Just started from random moves and refined itself.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: This self-play learning method means that it was not fed any data from humans and it did not observe games played by other AI systems either. The AI starts from scratch by playing randomly and gradually improves as it determines which actions and which probability distribution over those actions lead to better outcomes against earlier versions of its strategy, Brown and Sandholm write in their paper.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Kinda like how DeepMind tackled Go or OpenAI with Dota 2. But poker's so much trickier 'cause it's multiplayer, not just one-on-one.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Kinda like how DeepMind tackled Go or OpenAI with Dota two. But poker's so much trickier 'cause it's multiplayer, not just one-on-one.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: This strategy has been used before. For example, Google DeepMind used it to crack Go and OpenAI used it to master Dota 2.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Right, and real life is messy like that—auctions, traffic, negotiations. Not just zero-sum.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, and real life is messy like that-auctions, traffic, negotiations. Not just zero-sum.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Real-world scenariossuch as bidding in an online auction or navigating traffictypically involve multiple actors.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And they tested it against some serious competition. Chris Ferguson and Darren Elias were at the table!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And they tested it against some serious competition. Chris Ferguson and Darren Elias were at the table!
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Among the professionals were Chris Ferguson, the World Series of Poker champion, and Darren Elias, an American pro who holds the record for winning the most World Poker Tour titles.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and Pluribus was apparently winning something like $1,100 an hour if chips were real money. Per hand, uh, around six bucks on average.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and Pluribus was apparently winning something like one thousand, one hundred dollars an hour if chips were real money. Per hand, uh, around six bucks on average.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: There was no money at stake but the researchers claim that if each chip was worth a dollar, Pluribus would have won an average of about $5 per hand and would have made about $1,000 per hour playing against five humans.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: That's insane. And it did all that training for just $160 in cloud computing? Most AIs cost millions to train.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: That's insane. And it did all that training for just one hundred sixty dollars in cloud computing? Most AIs cost millions to train.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The researchers say they required just $150 worth of cloud computing resources.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Seriously, such a lean operation. They built on Libratus from 2017 but added a better search algorithm and faster self-play.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Seriously, such a lean operation. They built on Libratus from twenty seventeen but added a better search algorithm and faster self-play.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Pluribus is a supercharged version of another AI bot called Libratus, which beat human pros in two-player Texas holdem games in 2017. Unlike Libratus, Pluribus contains a new online search algorithm that can evaluate its options by searching a few moves ahead, as well as faster self-play algorithms.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Ferguson said it was super hard to predict—great at thin value bets on the river.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Ferguson said it was super hard to predict-great at thin value bets on the river.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Its really hard to pin him down on any kind of hand. Hes also very good at making thin value bets on the river and extracting value out of his good hands.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And Elias pointed out its mixed strategy execution. Humans just can't randomize perfectly like that, consistently.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And Elias pointed out its mixed strategy execution. Humans just can't randomize perfectly like that, consistently.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Elias added that Pluribus's main strength is its ability to use mixed strategies, which is what humans try to do. Its a matter of execution for humansto do this in a perfectly random way and to do so consistently, he says.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: It's almost unfair. But hey, at least pros don't have to worry about running into it online—Facebook's not open-sourcing it.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's almost unfair. But hey, at least pros don't have to worry about running into it online-Facebook's not open-sourcing it.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: We're not open sourcing itone reason were not is that poker is played commercially and we felt open sourcing could negatively impact the community, Facebook spokesman Ari Entin told Forbes.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, they said it could hurt the poker community if it went commercial. Smart move, honestly.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, they said it could hurt the poker community if it went commercial. Smart move, honestly.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: We're not open sourcing itone reason were not is that poker is played commercially and we felt open sourcing could negatively impact the community, Facebook spokesman Ari Entin told Forbes.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Still, makes you wonder what's next—healthcare algorithms learning through self-play? Traffic systems?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Still, makes you wonder what's next-healthcare algorithms learning through self-play? Traffic systems?

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Totally. Games are just the beginning.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Totally. Games are just the beginning.
